channel.title: Defense
channel.description: News, Analysis and Opinion from POLITICO

item.title: CIA ends publication of World Factbook reference tool
item.description: The site appeared online in 1997.

media:content.media:title: CIA Director John Ratcliffe arrives for a classified briefing with senators at the Capitol on Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Associated Press
item.dc:contributor: By Associated Press

item.title: Trump prepares to let go of arms control with Russia
item.description: Russian and U.S. nuclear arsenals could expand for the first time in three decades.

media:content.media:title: Russian ballistic missiles being prepared for a parade.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary

item.title: Trump’s Golden Dome, a year in, is struggling to take shape
item.description: The president vowed to build a missile defense shield for the country in three years. It’s nowhere close to being done.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump and Rep. Jim Banks (R-Ind.) listen as Space Force Gen. Michael Guetlein speaks in the Oval Office about the Golden Dome missile defense system May 20, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Audrey Decker

item.title: Cables show Trump’s moves on Greenland rattled other nations
item.description: State Department cables obtained by POLITICO lay bare the frustrations — and aspirations — of US allies and adversaries watching Trump seek the Danish island.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Bill Kuchman/POLITICO (source images via Getty Images and AP)
media:content.media:title: Main.Toosi.Greenland.jpg

item.dc:creator: By Nahal Toosi, Paul McLeary and Victor Jack
item.dc:contributor: By Nahal Toosi, Paul McLeary and Victor Jack

item.title: Poll: Trump voters support military intervention in more countries
item.description: 65 percent of Trump voters say the U.S. should take military action in at least one country, according to a new POLITICO poll.

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Anna Wiederkehr/POLITICO (source images via AP and Getty)
media:content.media:title: TPP-Venezuela-Foreign-Intervention

item.dc:creator: By Giselle Ruhiyyih Ewing and Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Giselle Ruhiyyih Ewing and Leo Shane III

item.title: US officials: More Ukraine, Russia talks coming next week
item.description: This week’s meetings were the first time all three countries sat face-to-face for talks to try and hash out a ceasefire.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy shake hands at the start of a joint news conference at Trump's Mar-a-Lago club, Dec. 28, 2025, in Palm Beach, Florida.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Felicia Schwartz
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Felicia Schwartz

item.title: Pentagon no longer views China threat as top priority
item.description: The National Defense Strategy, a dramatic shift from previous administrations, reinforces many of the military moves already undertaken by the president.

media:content.media:title: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth arrives to brief senators at the U.S. Capitol, Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch

item.title: ‘Old wine in a new bottle’: Greenland negotiations resemble an earlier deal
item.description: A 1951 treaty between the U.S. and Denmark already covers much of what a potential agreement on the island would include.

media:content.media:title: Vice President JD Vance gestures as he tours Pituffik Space Base on March 28, 2025, in Greenland.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Jack Detsch

item.title: Republicans narrowly fend off bid to limit Trump on Venezuela
item.description: GOP lawmakers pulled out all the stops to manage a tie vote and keep a war powers effort at bay a week after Senate Republicans quashed a similar measure.

media:content.media:title: Reps. Jim McGovern (D-Mass.), left, and Thomas Massie (R-Ky.) authorized the bipartisan war powers resolution to require President Donald Trump to seek congressional approval for renewed military action against Venezuela.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien

item.title: Trump stands down on Greenland — and Republicans exhale
item.description: GOP lawmakers insisted U.S. military force against the Arctic island was never actually an option.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump meets with NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte during a meeting on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, Jan. 21, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Joe Gould, Connor O'Brien and Leo Shane III

item.title: Trump orders active duty troops to prepare for Minnesota deployment
item.description: The move signals a potentially more harder-line approach by the White House.

media:content.media:title: People gather near the post office during a protest, Sunday, Jan. 18, 2026, in Minneapolis.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary

item.title: DHS turns on border chief over $2M office renovation plan
item.description: As DHS looks to increase deportations and build the wall, commissioner Rodney Scott requested a pricey office renovation project.

media:content.media:title: U.S. Customs and Border Protection commissioner Rodney Scott is being blamed for slow progress on construction of a wall along the border with Mexico.

item.dc:creator: By Daniel Lippman
item.dc:contributor: By Daniel Lippman

item.title: Confronted with thorny problems, Trump turns to the military
item.description: The president has used the armed forces during his second term as an initial option rather than a last resort.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump addresses a crowd of service members during a celebration open in honor of the Army's 250th anniversary on June 10, 2025, in Fort Bragg, North Carolina.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary

item.title: The World Cup’s most dreaded gatecrasher isn’t a fan but a drone
item.description: Officials from 11 American host cities met with military and law-enforcement leaders to game out security threats to the summertime tournament.

media:content.media:title: MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, New Jersey, will be the site of the World Cup final match in July. Local law-enforcement officials from the New York-New Jersey region were recently trained by FBI officials in the use of counter-drone technology as part of security preparations.

item.dc:creator: By Sophia Cai
item.dc:contributor: By Sophia Cai

item.title: Defense Department to overhaul military newspaper Stars and Stripes
item.description: The paper, which traces its roots back to the Civil War, receives some funding from the Pentagon and its staff is Defense Department employees.

media:content.media:title: Pentagon spokesperson Sean Parnell wrote on X that Stars and Stripes will be "modernized" to focus on “ALL THINGS MILITARY."

item.dc:creator: By Cheyanne M. Daniels
item.dc:contributor: By Cheyanne M. Daniels

item.title: Senate Republicans derail effort to rebuke Trump on Venezuela
item.description: Two Republicans who initially supported the measure flipped after extensive lobbying by the Trump administration.

media:content.media:title: Sen. Tim Kaine (left), listens as Sen. Rand Paul speaks with reporters at the Capitol, Jan. 7, 2026, in Washington.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien and Jordain Carney
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien and Jordain Carney

item.title: Why Trump doesn’t need to own Greenland to build Golden Dome
item.description: Much of the president’s signature defense shield isn’t even supposed to be based on land.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump, (left) Sen. Dan Sullivan, R-Alaska, and Sen. Kevin Cramer, R-N.D., listen as Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth speaks in the Oval Office about the Golden Dome initiative, May 20, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Audrey Decker
item.dc:contributor: By Audrey Decker

item.title: US personnel evacuated from Qatar base amid Iran tensions
item.description: The move comes as the Trump administration weighs options to punish Tehran over its crackdown on protesters.

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump arrives to address troops at the Al Udeid Air Base southwest of Doha on May 15, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary and Nahal Toosi
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary and Nahal Toosi

item.title: Trump says he has many military options on Iran. He doesn’t.
item.description: Many of the troops and ships once at the president’s disposal have shifted to the Caribbean.

media:content.media:credit: Middle East Images/AFP via Getty Images
media:content.media:title: Iranians gather during a protest in Tehran, Iran, on Friday.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch, Paul McLeary and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch, Paul McLeary and Joe Gould

item.title: Trump to be briefed on range of options in Iran
item.description: The options being presented to Trump would range from targeted strikes inside Iran to offensive cyber attacks.

media:content.media:title: Protesters participate in a demonstration in front of the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, Germany, in support of the mass protests in Iran against the government Jan. 11, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Sophia Cai, Felicia Schwartz, Paul McLeary and Jacob Wendler
item.dc:contributor: By Sophia Cai, Felicia Schwartz, Paul McLeary and Jacob Wendler

item.title: The one issue where Democrats think Trump is right
item.description: The president’s populist-style attack on defense industry executives is part of a larger Pentagon strategy to transform the role of suppliers.

media:content.media:title: An F35 Lockheed Martin fighter jet flies at the Paris Air Show on June 17, 2025 in Le Bourget, north of Paris.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch, Paul McLeary and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch, Paul McLeary and Joe Gould

item.title: NSA taps new second-in-command Tim Kosiba after months of uncertainty
item.description: The Pentagon spy agency has backed away from its original appointment of Joe Francescon as NSA deputy director in August.

media:content.media:title: Tim Kosiba is a 30-year veteran of the National Security Agency and the FBI.

item.dc:creator: By John Sakellariadis
item.dc:contributor: By John Sakellariadis

item.title: Senate votes to limit Trump on Venezuela
item.description: The procedural vote is a rare critique of Trump’s authority in the first test of GOP loyalty since last weekend’s capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro.

media:content.media:title: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and Sen. Tim Kaine, co-sponsor of the latest war powers measure, prepare to speak with reporters after senators were briefed by Trump administration officials about Venezuela operations on Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien

item.title: US could run Venezuela for years, Trump says
item.description: “We will rebuild it in a very profitable way,” he said in an interview with The New York Times.

media:content.media:title: Venezuelan government supporters hold dolls depicting late Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez, former Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and Maduro's wife, Cilia Flores, during a rally Wednesday, Jan. 7, in Caracas.

item.dc:creator: By Gregory Svirnovskiy
item.dc:contributor: By Gregory Svirnovskiy

item.title: Trump calls for record $1.5 trillion defense budget, a 50 percent jump
item.description: The president offered few details in his post on Truth Social, other than to say the money would pay for his “Dream Military.”

media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump acknowledges the crowd as House Majority Whip Tom Emmer (left) and House Speaker Mike Johnson applaud on Jan. 27, 2025 in Doral, Florida.

item.dc:creator: By Paul McLeary, Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Paul McLeary, Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould

item.title: GOP lawmakers denounce Trump’s threats to seize Greenland
item.description: “This is a topic that should be dropped," said Senate Armed Services Chair Roger Wicker.

media:content.media:title: A boat rides though a frozen sea inlet outside of Nuuk, Greenland on March 6, 2025.

item.dc:creator: By Connor O'Brien, Joe Gould and Leo Shane III
item.dc:contributor: By Connor O'Brien, Joe Gould and Leo Shane III

item.title: Trump officials tell Congress: No troops in Venezuela
item.description: A closed-door Senate briefing with national security leaders about the capture of Nicolás Maduro did little to sway the entrenched positions of each party.

media:content.media:title: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth, center, arrives to brief members of Congress on Capitol Hill, Jan. 7, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Leo Shane III, Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould
item.dc:contributor: By Leo Shane III, Connor O'Brien and Joe Gould

item.title: CIA turncoat Aldrich Ames, who sold secrets to the Soviets, dies in prison at 84
item.description: His betrayals were blamed for the deaths of Western agents.

media:content.media:title: FBI agents arrest CIA officer Aldrich Ames, center, over car, in Arlington, Virginia, on Feb. 21, 1994.

item.dc:creator: By Associated Press
item.dc:contributor: By Associated Press

item.title: Where Trump could strike next
item.description: From Venezuela to Greenland, Trump is exerting his global influence.

media:content.media:title: map: trump intervention

item.dc:creator: By Sean McMinn
item.dc:contributor: By Sean McMinn

item.title: Venezuela operation magnifies Pentagon's shift west — and away from China
item.description: The capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro underscored the administration’s pivot toward the Western Hemisphere, further unraveling decades of bipartisan consensus that prioritized Beijing as America’s top global threat.

media:content.media:credit: Molly Riley/The White House via AP
media:content.media:title: President Donald Trump, CIA Director John Ratcliffe, Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth monitor U.S. military operations in Venezuela from Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, Florida, Jan. 3, 2026.

item.dc:creator: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
item.dc:contributor: By Jack Detsch and Paul McLeary
